Hello -- sorry I (or anyone else from fsgames) hasn't responded recently .. 
we're all pretty much on vacation at the moment, and have been avoiding 
e-mail (and playing with toys instead) when possible :)

>The reason that the game crashed is pretty easy to pinpoint.  A level 5
>mage with 20 intelligence has more mana than a level 1 mage with 20
>intelligence.  Gladiator was programmed in C, which has limits to the
>variables -- when these limits are crossed, the variables plunge into the
>realm of negatives.  Various calculations that the game performs could
>cause program upsets that causes it to crash.

It's not specifically due to using C, but rather what limits and checks we 
put into the game.  We used 16-bit values for most of the in-game 
variables, which we felt was a reasonable limit for any "real" team 
:)  Chris is perfectly right about weird behavior when those values are 
exceeded -- they can become negative, which really confuses formulas, or 
they can just misbehave in general when they're too big .. especially if a 
formula is something like x*x, or x*y*z, or even (yikes!) x^2....

In the most common cases, we put in checks to make sure this doesn't cause 
problems, but with super-high values, there are definitely places in the 
game that can get confused (ie, crash or behave really strangely).

>The reason that your editor and game crashes when your grid is too
>large is probably because the game does not allocate enough memory
>from the heap to hold the data effectively.  This anomoly is, once
>again, good recipe for a crash.

I think (I don't have the source in front of me, so I'm not sure), that the 
grid was hard-coded as a 256x256 maximum tile size.  That's because when we 
first created the simple "pix" graphic format, we used single-byte values 
to define the X and Y dimensions .. most of our early scenarios were more 
like 60x100 in size, so we figured we had plenty of room :)

>The reasons behind this are probably because you're pushing the game
>to its limits.  I believe that, fundamentally, gladiator should be able to
>operate on a 386 without too much hampering by the system's
>resources (or lack thereof).  I think that this is how the game was
>originally designed without enormous scenarios being taken into mind.

That's pretty much correct, also :)  We optimized a lot of Gladiator to 
make sure that it ran fine on a 386-style machine with one megabyte of 
memory :)  A 486 with, say, 8 megs of memory could make the game fly and be 
very happy ;-)

Because of that, there were things we did that would be different if we did 
a special "new processor" style upgrade today :)  Things like limits on 
object/scenario sizes, speed settings (playing the game on '10' is 
basically unplayable on any modern system), etc., were all designed for 
older/slower/smaller systems.

>This touches again on my proposal that the level designers out there
>design scenarios with a starting team in mind -- without the
>expectation that the player's characters will reach levels in the
>hundreds.

Definitely true.  Basically, what we did to try to play-balance the 
scenarios was to start a number of teams, from scratch, and play through 
all our existing scenarios.  This let us test to make sure that, for 
example, level 6 wasn't suddenly twice as hard, or twice as easy, as level 
5 or 7 .. and it let us tweak values (how much gold is on a level, how many 
monster generators are there, etc.) until we got levels that seemed to play 
right, from the start.

Of course, playing new, player-made levels, with new characters (ie, the 
ArchMage was designed later, and never really meant to fit into the 'early' 
scenarios) can drastically alter how the game balance feels!

Take care,
    Tom
